title: bar owner bristol alcohol drinks water pubs
story: Co-founder of hipster bar Bristol Spirit, Sam Espensen, said  customers ordered water last week and believes its a nationwide problem as bars rely on drink sales to stay alive.Sam took to Twitter to share her thoughts, saying customers often order food when visiting the bar, but often ask for free tap water instead of spending money on drinks from the menu.In a since-deleted tweet, she wrote: If you come to Bristol Spirit and only drink free tap water - we will not make enough money from your table to break even, let alone turn a profit.If you just ask for tap water, it feels like you are telling us you dont value our business enough to buy a drink, which is the reason we exist.Bristol Spirit serves naturally infused spirits as well as local beers, wine and soft drinks, but more recently the sales of alcoholic drinks has gone down.She told Bristol Live: This is happening across the industry. This is partly down to people wanting to drink healthier or non alcoholic drinks, but as we offer around  dferent options for those not wanting to drink alcohol it certainly cant account for all of them.Bar and restaurants margins are already cut to the bone, thanks to a myriad of ever increasing overheads including wages going up , food price increases, utility bills, the sugar tax, etc.Were expected to cater to vegan, gluten free, dairy free and all sort of other diets, as well as many people expecting locally bought, organic, free range produce.Sam wants people to realise the costs that go into making her bar a “wonderful place,” and previously told Bristol Live about the high hidden costs incurred from paying for CCTV, menu printing and property maintenance.She saidpeople continue ordering tap water, it will affect the bar and pub trade - which she said is contending with enough already.She added: I dont have the answer on how to address this problem, I just want to have a conversation about it so that people know that the issue exists.

title: legal firm four day week pay rise plymouth
story: The sht in work days at Portcullis Legals saw the Plymouth firm become the first workplace in south west England to convert to four-day work weeks.Managing director Trevor Worth said: The initial results have been heartening - our team is happier and our customers are receiving a better service.Bosses at Portcullis Legals said staff and customers are happier after the change, which sees the office open later into the evening.The firm raised pay to eliminate concerns that the change in hours might just be a cost-cutting exercise.Successful schemes that have been tested around the world have seen employees working fewer hours but being more productive with their time.Bosses say the change has boosted morale and motivation.A study of a trial at a New Zealand financial firm found workers were % more productive - improving both profits and staff well-being, reported Plymouth Live.Seeing the results, the bosses at Portcullis ran its own five-month trial.The company, which has nine staff and works from the innovative Law Store in Plymstock, is now fully implementing the initiative.Mr Worth said: I’ve contacted businesses far and wide to find out the benefits and pitfalls of the four-day week, working with academics and industry leaders to find out the best way to apply the four-day week to Portcullis.The response has been extraordinary and there’s a real passion to help other firms achieve a happier working week for their staff.Our staff have been more motivated and productive - I’m delighted we’ve been able to make it work and provide an even better service for customers, and a great working environment for our team. Values and purpose are very important to us, as is the well-being of every team member.A string of small British firms have switched their workers over to a four-day week in the past six months.Companies who took the plunge include Synergy Vision, a medical communications agency, Elektra Lighting, a lighting design company, Lara Intimates, which makes underwear, and the Intrepid Camera company, which makes and exports photographic equipment.The sht has inspired many other companies to trial the four-day week before fully committing.

title: groom glassed face night before wedding
story: Ex-cop Scott Richards was left needing  stitches when half-naked thug Tyler Plumridge rammed a pint glass into his face.Docs spent the night picking shards of glass out of his eyes - but he still tied the knot with fiance Adele,  the next day.He said: She told me she was glad I was here and that she was marrying me for who I am as a person – not for my looks. That brought another lump to my throat.It’s meant to be the best day of your le but when I look back I’ll always remember I got glassed the night before.He was glassed after confronting Plumridge on a night out in Ashford, Kent - after the tanked-up security guard pinched his wallet and phone.Scott ordered him to empty his pockets - but Plumridge stripped to his boxers and smashed a glass of beer into his face.Scott added: All I could see was blood. I collapsed to the floor.”“As my friends tried to stem the blood, they said, ‘It’s not too bad.’ But I looked at my brother and could see in his face how bad it was.He was in floods of tears and told me my nose was half hanging off and I had glass in my eye.I was crying. All I could think was, ‘I’m not getting married. I’ve ruined it all.Adele, , who works in ­marketing, added: When I first saw him as I walked up the aisle my stomach lurched, I thought I might be sick. I just couldn’t bear to see how bad the damage was.Scott was forced to put a brave face on it for our wedding day but it was clear he wasn’t himself.He definitely isn’t the same carefree person he was before the attack. He’s much more wary and anxious now and gets uncomfortable in busy, loud places.Vile Plumridge was handed a -month suspended sentence at Canterbury crown court after pleading guilty to grievous bodily harm.He was also ordered to do  hours of unpaid community work, and pay Scott £, compensation.

title: marine le pen victory eu elections macron defeat
story: The -year-old poured scorn on President Emmanuel Macron, , as early estimates put her National Rally on just over  per cent of the popular vote.Mr Macron’s pro-EU en Marche is forecast to come in second with . percent.In celebratory speech, Ms Le Pen said: “It is the President and his policies that are rejected.”She added: “The French people have made their voice heard with unexpected force.“This is immensely satisfying for all of those who have never ceased to believe in France.”Sources close to Mr Macron meanwhile said that he was “satisfied with a result that was not unexpected.”This is despite him projecting the election as an “existential moment” in Europe’s fight against populism in Europe.Mr Macron has been struggling to cope with a number of threats since coming to power in , including the anti-government Yellow Vests movement which has been rioting in major French cities since November.The election results will translate to his newly-formed party gaining  seats in the European Parliament, while the National Rally will get .This does not represent a signicant gain for the Le Pen’s party, which was called the National Frontuntil last year when it was rebranded.Despite being a Eurosceptic party, the National Rally has used the European Parliament to raise its profile, especially as it has found it hard to win seats in the National Assembly, France’s domestic parliament.Ms Le Pen’s father, anti-Semite Jean-Marie Le Pen, founded the FN as an extreme nationalist party, but his daughter has tried to soften its image.Mr Le Pen has just stood down as an MEP and Marine is now relying on far-Right allies in countries such as Austria and Italy to push her anti-immigrant agenda.She has rejected moves towards a Frexit – getting France out of the EU – instead saying she wants to reform the bloc from within.It was also a good night for the Greens in France, as polls put them on  per cent of the popular vote.

title: dog owner paid rods down husky throat pennsylvania
story: Anne Beiler, , hired vet Denise Felling to do the job because she was sick of the noise made by her two huskies.The illegal procedure was performed in a filthy outbuilding at Beiler’s home in Lancaster County, Pennsylvania. Beiler’s two Doberman pinschers were also “debarked” by someone . The cruelty was uncovered after the Pennsylvania Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals workers seized  dogs from Beiler’s farm in May .They had been alerted by someone concerned for their welfare.A further nine puppies were found to have had their tails improperly docked, with rubber bands wrapped tightly around them.Beiler pleaded guilty to animal cruelty charges and was sentenced to two years’ probation. She was ordered to surrender all of the dogs she owns bar one.She was also banned from working with or looking after dogs during the duration of her probation. Meanwhile Felling admitted four counts of debarking dogs – Beiler’s husky, as well as three others on neighbouring homes, Lancaster Online reported. She was sentenced to  months’ jail, but immediately released because of the time she had spent behind bars awaiting trial.

title: no deal brexit esther mcvey tory leadership election
story: The Tory leadership contender said she will immediately end Brexit talksshe becomes PM.Instead she will aim to take Britain out on October  without a deal unless Brussels offers a much better deal instead.Ms McVeys hardline stance is intended to show she is the ultimate Brexiteer candidate ahead of Boris Johnson and Dominic Raab.She told Sky News today: October  is the key date and we are coming out then, andthat means without a deal then thats what it means.We wont be asking for any more extensions. If Europe wants to come back to us, the door is openthey want a better deal.Time is limited, we have to make sure we are ready to leave.The ex-Work and Pensions Secretary dismissed the idea of reopening talks on the existing Brexit deal.Mr Raab said he would prioritise restarting talks on getting a better deal with Brussels - but insisted hes prepared for No Dealnecessary, even though the Commons is opposed.He said: Its very dficult for Parliament now to legislate against No Deal unless a Prime Minister is willing to acquiesce in this - and Im not.But Chancellor Philip Hammond insisted that the new PM wont be able to governthey go for a No Deal.He told the BBC: I think it would be very dficult for a prime minister who adopted No Deal as a policy to retain the confidence of the House of Commons.Dozens of Tories - and nearly all opposition MPs - would be fiercely against any attempt to leave without a deal.But its not clear whether or not they would actually be able to block it using parliamentary procedure.

title: labour brexit second referendum john mcdonnell
story: Deputy leader Tom Watson and Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell both said there should be a second vote on Brexit.They admitted Labours fence-sitting policy has failed with the party on course for a terrible result in the Euro elections.When results are announced tonight the party is almost certain to be beaten by Nigel Farages Brexit Party and could come third behind the Lib Dems.Mr McDonnell told Sky News: I think we most probably will get a good kicking in the election results tonight - well see, but were braced for that.He invited the leaders of other parties to join talks on pushing for a second referendum to prevent a No Deal Brexit under the next PM.The Shadow Chancellor added: We now need to have that discussion about how we can prevent damage to the economy.If that means going back to the people, yes lets go back to the people.Mr McDonnell is Jeremy Corbyns closest friend and political ally.Deputy leader Tom Watson also insisted Labour must now change its policy to back a second referendum come what may.Writing in The Observer, he said: For our partys sake, but most of all for Britains sake, Labour needs to find some backbone on Brexit, find our voice - and do it fast.Our performance is a direct result of our mealy-mouthed backing for a public vote on Brexit when it is being demanded loud and clear by the overwhelming majority of our members and voters.But in a sign of the massive splits within Labour, powerful union boss Len McCluskey warned the party would alienate Leave voters by going for a second referendum.The partys current policy is to push for a soft Brexit deal or a General Election, and only back a referendumthose prove impossible.

title: theresa makes first public appearance
story: NewsTheresa May makes first public appearance since teary resignationThe Prime Minister was smiling as she kept her routine of attending church in her constituencyShareCommentsByOliver MilnePolitical Correspondent:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsTheresa May "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May has made her first public appearance since she announced her resignation on Friday. The Prime Minister - who said she will stand down as Tory leader on June  and PM after her party pick her successor - was at church this morning with her husband Philip. Mrs May broke cover to attend the weekly service at St Andrews church in her Maidenhead constituency as fellow Tories were locked in the opening salvos of a brutal race to succeed her. Vicars daughter Mrs May looked relaxed as she greeted a friendly dog, named Blitz and walked with her husband to the service. This morning Brexiteer Michael Gove, torpedoed Boris Johnsonaposs leadership bid in , announced that he is to have another attempt at becoming prime minister.    Speaking outside his west London home Mr Gove said: I can confirm that I will be putting my name forward to be prime minister of this country.I believe that Iaposm ready to unite the Conservative and Union Party, ready to deliver Brexit , and ready to lead this great country.It puts him on a collision course with Boris Johnson, who is the frontrunner in the race.    The race has become a crowded field. As of Sunday morning - alongside Boris and Mr Gove - Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt, Health Secretary Matt Hancock, International Development Secretary Rory Stewart  and ex-Cabinet ministers Dominic Raab, Esther McVey and Andrea Leadsom had thrown their hats into the ring. But former minister Justine Greening has ruled herself out of the race and branded it a beauty parade for hard Brexiteers.    Ms Greening told Sophy Ridge on Sunday that the leadership contest is a narrow discussion in a narrow Conservative Party thataposs really around what version of hard Brexit to do. She added: This should and could be a leadership contest that was about hard choices for the Conservative Party. Instead it is really just going to be a beauty parade of hard Brexiteers. I am not going to be in it.

title: boy 14 becomes full time
story: NewsBoy, , becomes full time carer for his young siblings after dad walks outEmma Lowe, , from Preston, Lancashire has praised her son Harry for taking on the role of man of the houseShareCommentsByAnn CusackLaura Forsyth:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsHarry puts in a -hour day to help with his siblings Arthur and Alfies care "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A schoolboy has become a full time carer for his five siblings after his dad walked out on the family. Emma Lowe, , who is a single mum of seven – including twins with Downs Syndrome - has paid tribute to her son Harry.The -year-old has been putting in a  hour day to help with their care - taking on the role of aposman of the houseapos. Harryaposs siblings are Thomas, , Benjamin, , twins Arthur and Alfie, six, and four-year-old Elsie. Emma tragically lost a daughter, Molly, aged five months, who also had Downs Syndrome. Her husband walked out soon after her youngest child was born – leaving Emma to cope alone. The former teacher, from Preston, Lancashire, said: “It was a very daunting prospect, especially with two disabled children. “But Harry stepped in and became the man of the house. He is absolutely incredible and I couldn’t cope without him.    “Most -year-olds are out with their mates, having fun, or lazing around. But Harry never gets a minute to himself. He looks out for the twins all the time, just like a parent would. I would just like him to get the credit and the recognition he deserves.” Emma’s heartache began when her daughter, Molly, was born in March , and diagnosed with Downs Syndrome, a hole in the heart and underdeveloped lungs. She died five months later. Emma said: It was heartbreaking and very hard for my older children. We call Molly’s grave her ‘forever bed’ and we visit her all the time.” Emma’s twin sons, Alfie and Arthur, were born in July , and she was stunned when they, too, were diagnosed with Downs Syndrome. She says: “The chances of having three babies with Downs Syndrome were a million to one. But when the midwe held Alfie up, I recognised the features, just like Molly. The condition itself didn’t scare me because I knew I could cope but I was scared, after losing Molly, that the same thing might happen again.”    Arthur and Alfie thankfully did not have the same medical challenges as Molly, though they were later diagnosed with autism. They are also non-verbal and need wheelchairs. The year after the twins were born, Emma had a daughter, Elsie. But without warning, her husband, David, walked out. Her eldest son, Thomas, also left home to go to college – leaving Harry as man of the house. Emma says: “Harry just naturally fell into the role of young carer. It wasn’t what I wanted for him and I certainly didn’t push him into it.  “But he loved caring for the boys and he quickly became invaluable. I really couldn’t cope without him now. “Harry and Alfie in particular have a very special bond. Alfie is completely non-verbal except for one word: ‘Harry.’ Unlike most boys his age, Harry is up at .am to bath and dress his brothers. He will then help feed them whilst having his own breakfast and getting ready for school. Emma says: “By the time he goes to school, he has often been on the go for three hours, watching the twins, keeping them safe, playing with them, and then lting them onto their school bus when it comes.”    And the evenings are just as hectic. Emma, said: “Harry will change nappies, wash clothes, cook meals. He can cook steak and spaghetti Bolognese. “He helps put the twins to bed with me and then, late at night, we will reheat our evening meal and eat together. It can be midnight by the time our tasks are all finished. “Even during the night,the twins wake up crying, he is there with them. I try to make sure he gets his sleep but he wants to look after them. “And when we go out, Harry is on hand to make sure the twins have a good time. He puts them before himself every time. “They both need wheelchairs for any distances so Harry will push one, I push the other, and Benjamin looks out for Elsie.” Harry is anxious to change the stigma around Downs Syndrome and is involved in support groups and charity work.    Emma says: “Harry has even given talks on his brothers. He wants to make people more aware and more accepting. “People have no idea what le is like for him – and other young carers. He adores his brothers but looking after them is demanding and dficult sometimes. “But I know he wouldn’t change them for the world.” Harry says: “When I say I’m a carer, most people presume I look after a parent, but I look after my siblings. I think siblings who care for siblings don’t get the support or the recognition they need. “I don’t get asked to do this. I do it to support my brothers and to help my mum. My mum does a great job, she’s a superhero, and I hope, through telling my story, I can raise awareness of the need for more help and support.”

title: british spies smuggled secrets putins
story: NewsBritish spies smuggled secrets about Putins new supersonic bomber using loose teaRussian air crews unwittingly helped to smuggle Russian defence intelligence into the hands of British spiesShareCommentsByKaisha Langton:,  MAY NewsThe plan was carried out unwittingly by Russian pilots who journeyed to Venezuela with the tea "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBritish spies managed to smuggle secrets about multi-million pound upgrades to Russiaaposs supersonic bombers out of the country using an unusual method - through loose leaf tea, it has emerged. The audacious plan was carried out unwittingly by Russian pilots who journeyed to Venezuela with the tea, where an agent then picked up the discarded box. The information was then used by Western forces to help identy vulnerabilities in the planes, an intelligence source revealed.British spies from MI worked with the CIA and Mossad, the national intelligence agency of Israel to hatch the plans, MailOnline reports. The aim was to find out more about Russiaaposs supersonic TU- bombers, known as Blackjacks.   The plot involved a Russian crew drinking tea during a flight from Russia to Caracas with secrets stashed at the bottom of the packet by a Western source placed in Russia.According to The Sunday Express , the bomberaposs upgrades have transformed its defensive capabilities which make it dficult for enemy fighters to lock onto it.In the wake of the Novichok attack in Salisbury last year, diplomatic tensions between Russia and the West are fraught and the intelligence agencies had to come up with a plan to extract information whilst avoiding sending spies into the country. A solution came in the most quintessentially of British solutions - tea.  Spies discovered Putin was sending two Blackjacks to Venezuela in a show of support to President Nicolas Maduro in December, . Russia relies upon the re-selling of Venezuelan oil and gas and had signed a pact with Hugo Chavez in .Putin seized the opportunity to display the bombers off the US coast and so a plan was then hatched for the information to be carried unknowingly on one of these Blackjacks.It was stored at the bottom of a packet of loose Russian Caravan tea that was on board the bomber aircraft. Agents even had to calculate how much tea the pilots would drink during the -hour flight.  If there was too much, the packet would not be thrown away.  When the plane landed at Simon Boli airport in Venezuela, an agent retrieved the discarded packet and then took it to a CIA officer waiting at a hotel in Caracas. The secrets were taken to the US for analysis before it was shared with UK and Nato forces. An intelligence source told MailOnline:  An hour after landing, a quantity of rubbish, which included the tea packet, was taken from the aircraft while it was being refuelled. The packet, which contained a small amount of tea, was among items placed in a rubbish disposal point. That it worked was due, in no small part, to luck, but such is the way with many operations.apos

The passengers who were heading to Benidorm were seen guzzling alcohol from a funnel on their flight.Each took turns filming themselves chugging from the bong on board the early morning journey from London Stansted to Alicante. One was seen lying on his back in the aisle as his friends poured the contents of two beer cans into the funnel he had connected into his mouth. Footage shows the group roaring with laughter when it spilled over him. An air stewardess was seen trying to calm the men down, when one of the party asked her: “Can you hold it up ” She seemed to tell them that “this is fine” in broken English before disappearing from the camera shot.    The flight attendant appeared to make no attempt to stop them as they poured more beer for another man wearing an armband and football top. As he ended up covered in lager, one of his friends shouted: “It’s a waterfall.”  They carried on with their shenanigans without any intervention from the flight crew for several minutes. Beer was poured straight from the can onto anotheraposs face while someone shouted: “Top it up.”  The man holding centre stage from the aisle carried on drinking before shouting: “Have you got any more ” The revellers then proceeded to dance and sing in the aisle - with one placing the funnel upside down on his head as the others chanted: “He’s got a beer bong on his head.”  Seconds later one of the party threw more lager over a mate who reacted by laughing: “Spillage in the village.” The incident is understood to have happened on board the .am Ryanair flight from London Stansted to Alicante on Saturday.  The men - who numbered around  - were believed to be heading to Benidorm for a lads’ holiday.  Ryanair have been approached for comment regarding the incident.  A video emerged last year of an intoxicated Irish woman and her partner being taken off a Ryanair plane from Alicante to Dublin which was forced to make an unscheduled stop in the northern Spanish city of Santander. At the time, a Ryanair spokesman commented: “We will not tolerate unruly or disruptive behaviour at any time and the safety and comfort of our customers, crew and aircraft is our number one priority.”

title: dark secret behind dull steel
story: NewsDark secret behind dull steel door passed by hundreds of people every dayThe grey door in Hull city centre now forms part of a souvenir and convenience store - but it has a tragic pastShareCommentsByMike CovellDan Kemp:,  MAY NewsThe door is now part of a shop but hides a tragic history "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA seemingly dull steel door located in a busy city centre once hid a very dark secret behind it. Located in Hull, the grey doorway is now part of a recently opened souvenir and convenience store. Every day, hundreds of people walk past it, unaware of the notorious and tragic past that lies behind it.But the door once led to an infamous slum known as “Bartle’s Entry”, according to historian Mike Covell. Hull Live reports that within seven small houses lived seven families and  people.There was no running water – not even a communal tap – no toilets, inside or out, and no heating.The slum was also re with crime . It took its name from John Bartle, a miller and baker of ships’ biscuits, who operated from    Whitefriargateas early as . By the s, he was a success and opened a mill roughly where RB stands today at the corner with Mount Pleasant.Soon, though, tragedy struck. In , his son, John Junior, lost his we Jane just months after they were married. She was . Two years later, Bartle’s eldest son, James, died at just . Still, his business went from strength to strength and newspapers often featured adverts for his bread, biscuits and confectionery.    In , Bartle died at his Whitefriargate warehouse and John Junior took over. A few years later, records reveal the state of the notorious slum that sat next to the thriving business. Crammed into the shocking accommodation were the Reed family, the Moment family, the Robinson family, the Greenwood family, the Squires family and the Hill family. Conditions were said to have been truly appalling which is likely to have been the cause of deaths that followed. Among the many stories from the short history of Bartle’s Entry is the death of William King, who was found leless in his bed by his we in April . He went to bed without complaining of any illness and mystery still surrounds what killed him. Theft was another problem. The following year, police raided the slum and apprehended a William Johnson for stealing a large amount of clothes. As late as , an advertisement appeared in the Hull Daily Mail, offering houses in Bartle’s Entry to rent at three shillings per week. By then, the Bartle family had left and their bakery had been converted first into an umbrella warehouse and then into a branch of the Yorkshire Post newspaper. The slum houses, now recognised as unfit for human habitation, were closed and condemned at about the time of the First World War.

title: entire 18 acre ancient roman
story: NewsEntire -acre Ancient Roman town discovered next to major motorwayRare coins and jewellery dating back to AD have also been uncovered near the A in Newington, KentShareCommentsByLaura ForsythIsabel DobinsonEllis Stephenson:,  MAY NewsAn -acre settlement dating back as early as  AD has been uncovered "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email An entire Ancient Roman town including a temple and main road has been uncovered buried next to a major motorway . This discovery has been hailed one of the most signicant finds in regional archaeological history.The -acre settlement, which contains rare coins, pottery and jewellery, dates back as early as  AD. It has been uncovered next to the A in Newington, Kent. The site includes remains of a temple which has since been named Watling Temple - making it one of only  sites recorded in England. Archaeologists also uncovered an ancient seven-metre road which is believed to have been an alternative route to the A which runs from London to Kentish coast.    Experts have hailed the discovery as one of the most signicant finds in the region - but the newly revealed settlement is destined to become new homes as part of a Persimmon Homes new development. Chairman of Newington History Group Dean Coles said: This is very exciting. The scale of this site, with the huge number and quality of finds, changes our knowledge of Newingtonaposs development. We already had evidence of a Roman burial ground and Roman occupation in the immediate vicinity and this excavation shows there was a thriving manufacturing site in the heart of our village. The temple and major road are massive discoveries. It proves the A wasnapost the only Roman road through the village.    As a group, we are keen to trace the route and destination of this new aposhighwayapos which may have connected with another temple excavated  years ago on the outskirts of Newington and a villa unearthed in . Experts will analyse the findings and publish a report but the ancient remains will once again be covered up to make way for the housing development. Archaeological director at Swale and Thames Archaeological Survey, Doctor Paul Wilkinson said: This is one of the most important discoveries of a Roman small town in Kent for many years with the preservation of Roman buildings and artefacts exceptional. Archaeology project manager Peter Cichy added: This is one of the most signicant sites in Kent but itaposs only the beginning of months and months of work. We will be analysing and dating our finds, sorting and piecing together thousands of pottery shards and writing up our report. Romans invaded Britain in  AD and remained for almost  years. Remains of their occupation have been found scattered across the UK - including Hadrianaposs Wall in Northumberland and the Roman Baths in Bath.

title: former deputy head teacher caught
story: NewsFormer deputy head teacher caught drink driving to Aldi with baby in the carSamantha Rae, , was seen swerving across the road with her -month-old son in the car before getting out at her local AldiShareByTom MackKaisha Langton:,  MAY NewsSamantha Rae, , was caught drink driving on her way to the Aldi on Watling Street, Hinckley "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA former deputy head teacher got drunk and drove her toddler son to Aldi so they could get pudding. A concerned driver who had been following her along the A near Hinckley called the police as soon as they saw Rae’s -month-old son was also in the car when it stopped at the townaposs local Aldi. The mother was breathalysed and found to be over the drink-driving limit. She was arrested and pleaded guilty to drink-driving on Friday when she appeared at Leicester Magistrates’ Court. Prosecutor Sally Bedford told the court: “It was about .pm on May  when a witness called  having followed this defendant on the A. “They were concerned by the standard of the defendant’s driving.  She was driving on the wrong side of the road and when she pulled over and got out of the car she was staggering all over the place and tripped up the kerb. “There appeared to be a small child with her.” She added that Leicestershire Police attended and found Rae appeared to be “extremely intoxicated”. Ms Bedford said: “She presented as being very much under the influence of alcohol. She was arrested and taken to the police station.” At the police station, the -year-old mum, of Bradgate Road, Hinckley, was breathalysed and found to have a reading of  microgrammes per ml of breath. The court heard Rae had been deputy head of a large British school in Shanghai, but had then moved to Indonesia, where she had started drinking a lot. Rae, who did not have legal representation, told the magistrates: “I’d just like to apologise profusely for my actions. title: nada farhoud urgently need ban
story: NewsopinionNada Farhoud: We urgently need to ban plastics that cannot be recycledIts time we all realised that many of the plastics we faithfully put in our recycling bins are secretly being burnedShareCommentsByNada Farhoud:,  MAY NewsopinionWith bewildering collection systems of multicoloured boxes, bins and bags, it is perhaps not surprising recycling rates have flatlined "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMillions of plastic pots, tubs and trays we diligently put in recycling bins are secretly being incinerated. Fty local authorities admit they are burning “low-grade” packaging made from ­polyethyleneas it’s so brittle it needs to be sent to specialist recycling facilities. The problem is we don’t have any. Until last year, China received two-thirds of it, then it shut up shop. Other countries receiving our waste have also imposed restrictions, leaving us to deal with it. So instead of being turned into products, it is burned to generate electricity. There is a logic to turning waste that can’t be recycled into energy rather than being sent to landfill. But only as the last resort. The  incinerators we have in England produce the same amount of toxic particulates each year as , lorries – contributing to air pollution and greenhouse gas emissions. I try my best to reuse packaging but when I do recycle, I want to know my efforts have not been betrayed by it all being shoved into a furnace.    England is on the brink of burning more rubbish that it recycles. While rates of domestic waste recycling have stalled since , incineration has tripled between   and  , although this is not due to a reluctance to recycle, or to do our bit for the environment. There is a huge gap between the best and worst local authorities. But this doesn’t mean people in Westminster or Birmingham, or any other area with poor recycling rates, can’t be bothered. The system just isn’t working. To find a way out of this pollution crisis we must ­radically reduce how much is produced in the first place. We need to ban plastics that can’t be recycled and businesses should set up proper systems for those that local authorities find most dficult. But in order to be able to stop burning rubbish and dumping it on vulnerable communities abroad, we must also get rid of our ludicrously complex and chaotic recycling system of over  dferent schemes. With bewildering collection systems of multicoloured boxes, bins and bags, it is perhaps not surprising recycling rates have flatlined. A nationally consistent system would mean every household in the country recycling the same items, helped by a set of easily recycled materials.

title: statue best woman footballer world
story: NewsStatue for best woman footballer in the world who was recruited at just As our Lionesses head to France, a statue of the first woman to be inducted into the National Football Museum Hall of Fame will be unveiledShareCommentsByAmanda Killelea:,  MAY NewsLily Parr played for Dick, Kerr Ladies which was run from a munitions factory in Preston, Lancs, where the factory girls took the footballing world by storm "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailChallenged to kick the ball as hard as she could a young Lily Parr squared up to the boy in goal and went for it – breaking his arm and giving birth to a legend. Born in , by the age of  she was recruited to her first woman’s team – one of many created during the First World War – and played for her country not much later in . Standing ft tall, the chain-smoking left-footed winger was an equal to any man – and one of the best players England has produced. In a -year career she scored nearly , goals. As our Lionesses prepare to head to the World Cup in France next month, Lily will become the first female ­footballer to have a statue when a le-size bronze monument is unveiled at Manchester’s National Football Museum in the same month.    Cousin June Patten, , says Lily would be proud but humble about the honour. “She was strong, she was forceful, she was determined,” says June. “It is safe to say she was the best woman ­footballer in the world. “We all knew her as ‘Our Lil” and we are proud that she was one of us. She may have been fearsome on the pitch, but off the pitch she was one of the kindest, most gentle, funny and loveliest people you could have met.” Lily was born in a rented house in St Helens, Merseyside, the fourth of labourer George Parr and his we Sarah’s seven children. She first honed her football skills playing alongside her brothers on waste ground near their rented family home. The local lads soon counted her as their equal with her fearsome reputation on the pitch becoming the stuff of local legend.    June explains: “The boys used to call for her and ask her to play football. She was just accepted as one of the lads. But one of them one day said to her I bet you can’t kick a ball hard. He said I’ll go in goal and you kick the ball at me. She kicked the ball so hard she broke his arm. She had a kick like a mule. She was a better footballer than all the boys.” It wasn’t long before Lily’s talents were spotted. It was towards the end of the First World War and most men were on the frontline fighting. Women took the helm working in mills and munitions factories in tough conditions, so bosses decided that taking up a sport like football in the fresh air would be good for them. So the beautul game became the women’s game with  ladies teams dotted across the country attracting crowds of thousands, and raising money for war charities. Dick, Kerr Ladies was the best of the bunch. It was run from a munitions factory in Preston, Lancs, with the factory girls grafting hard by day and taking the ­footballing world by storm at weekends.    Lily scored an incredible  goals for them in her first season. And she represented England in the first recognised women’s international ­football game, helping her country beat France -. When Dick, Kerr played St Helens Ladies on Boxing Day of , , people flocked to Goodison Park in Liverpool to watch the game, with ­thousands more said to be locked out. But just a year later, in spite of the popularity of women’s football, the ­Football Association banned women’s clubs from its grounds, deeming the sport “quite unsuitable for females”. The ban remained in place until the late s, but that did not stop Lily from continuing to play. She toured abroad with Dick, Kerr, staying with the team until  and scoring more than  goals in her career, making her England’s most prolic goal-scorer of all time. Lily was also known for her aggressive style of play, which didn’t always go down well with the referee or the opposition. In April  Parr and Hilda Durbar of Stoke United were sent off for fighting in Dick, Kerr Ladies’ ­fractious – win before , fans at The Old Recreation Ground.    But she also had a mischievous side – she was rumoured to swipe balls from the field and sell them for profit and asked for her wages to be ­supplemented with her beloved Woodbine cigarettes. June remembers that cheeky streak well, laughing: “She was a chain smoker. One day she was playing and the ball was at the other end of the field. “There was a man leaning over the rail smoking so she took his cigarette off him, took a big drag of it and then gave it him back. “The smoking didn’t seem to bother her though.” Her cousin lived with a woman called Mary, and June recalls: “Everyone was very proud of her. She used to come on a Sunday evening to my grandma’s house, she used to bring her friend Mary who was a lovely lady, she was delightful, and we used to look forward to her coming. “She and Mary were such a joy to be with. In those days people didn’t contemplate it, but looking back now they were very likely to be gay. They were a very happy couple. “But it didn’t register with us – they were just Lily and Mary.” Lily trained as a nurse working at ­Whittingham Mental Hospital, near Preston, until she retired. She died from breast cancer aged  in , but her legend lives on.    She was the first female footballer to be inducted into the Football Hall of Fame in , and next month her statue, commissioned by chocolate makers Mars, will be unveiled. Football historian Gail Newsham, who has written a book about the legendary Dick, Kerr Ladies team, says there is no doubt that Lily was one of ­England’s greatest players of all time. She says: “The power of her shot was always a great asset and her ability. She was naturally gted and fearless. “The longevity of her career makes her stand out too and enabled her to score so many goals. “The fact that she played for so long obviously shows her love of the game. She was always admired by team mates and opponents alike. “People now look up to her as being one of the first ‘stars’ of the game. There can’t be many more players,any, who have scored more goals than Lily did.”And Gail believes England’s ­Lionesses need look no further for inspiration than Lilythey want to bring the World Cup back homethis summer.“If they can believe in their own ability as Lily did in hers, they won’t go far wrong,” she says. “Be fearless and never give up. I am sure the ­Lionesses won’t let Lily, or the rest of the Dick, Kerr Ladies, down. Let’s hope football is coming home.”Get involved in all the action and support England’s Lionesses this summer on social media using the Mars hashtag #SupportHer

Ted Bundy, Charles Manson and aposSon of Samapos David Berkowitz were just some of the notorious killers who described their horric crimes in chilling detail to him. For years he hid his abhorrence for the murderers, rapists and assassins across the table, collecting valuable information which would help snare many of Americaaposs most dangerous criminals. “Some of them were charming, but it was a superficial charm,” the -year-old said, recounting his conversations with monsters. “It was like staring into the eye of a shark, they would have killed methey could.” Now Douglas, who pioneered criminal profiling at a time when many thought it was a waste of time, said he is not surprised that public interest in his work – and particularly in Bundy and Manson – has spiked. He was the inspiration for Netflix series Mindhunter, while “manipulative”, “sadistic” but “charismatic” Bundy, who confessed to murdering  women, is now the subject of a high profile documentary series and movie.    Douglas interviewed Bundy repeatedly while he was on Death Row – and revealed he had to warn a colleague who he thought was falling under his spell. The profiler – whose work took a huge toll on him, nearly costing him his le - also toldthat Bundy was nearly successful in convincing the bureau to prolong his le in exchange for his co-operation – but Douglas opposed it. Describing the killer – who featured in a recent Netflix documentary and was portrayed by Zac Efron in movie Extremely Wicked, Shockingly Evil and Vile – Douglas said: “He was ruthless and he was a sadist. “He was a manipulator and a necrophiliac, but he was also very charming and gregarious. “He made a full confession to me and another agent.  “Later I had to speak to that agent because I felt he got too close to Bundy, he almost reached the point of feeling sorry for him. “Bundy would act like he was a victim, he claimed that pornography caused him to act the way he did, but that was baloney. “I had to remind the agent that Bundy was very manipulative, and that he was acting this way because they were getting ready to fry him.” And Douglas said the ploy almost worked.  “I had a call saying they wanted to keep him alive so they could study him some more, but I said no, itaposs really not necessary,” Douglas recounted. “I said Iaposd got to know him fairly well, thereaposs nothing more he can tell us.” Not long afterwards, Bundy was executed in January , aged . But Douglas said that from Bundy he learned that many killersto the scene of their crimes - a fact that helped catch killer Gary Ridgway, who was responsible for  murders.  Regarding the serial killer and rapistaposs portrayal on film, the ex-FBI man said: “I donapost think heaposs gloried in the movies, but I would have liked to see more on the impact on the victims and their families. “These people destroy lives.” Another notorious figure who Douglas interviewed, Charles Manson, is set to be portrayed in upcoming movie Once Upon a Time In Hollywood, starring Leonardo DiCaprio and Brad Pitt.  Describing his meetings with Manson, the profiler recalled: “Heaposs ft ins, it surprised me how small he was. “He stood up on a chair to exert himself over us. I knew he was going to do that because it was something he would do on his ranch. He was very dficult to interview, and some were very intimidated by him. “I interviewed him a couple of times, he said aposYou have to give me something. They know in the yard that the FBI are here.apos “He said he wanted my sunglasses, which were a pair of Ray Bans. He wanted them so he could go back and show them that heaposd ripped us off. “So I gave him the sunglasses, and he talked.”  From Manson, Douglas learned how cult members carried out the murder of actress Sharon Tate and four others at her home in August . In the hope of starting a race war, follower Lynette Fromme also attempted to assassinate President Gerald Ford in Sacramento. “I used a lot of buzz words to try and win his confidence, I tried to blend in and use the phrases I knew the Manson family used,” Douglas revealed. “In the end he said I was as nutty as him. “He was so into the helter skelter of creating a race war that his followers wanted to show they could be a somebody.”  The profiler said interviews would normally take place inside prisons at night, because the jailed monsters would often feel more at ease. When this wasnapost possible, FBI agents would dim lights to make it as dark as possible while serial killers talked. Others who Douglas interviewed in the early days of profiling included murderers Gary Ridgway – who confessed to killing  – John Wayne Gacy, who killed , Edmund Kemper and Gary Speck. He said the case that still haunts him the most is that of Lawrence Bittaker and Roy Norris, who became known as the Tool Box Killers during a killing spree which claimed the lives of five women.  They raped and killed their teenage victims over a period of five months in Southern Calornia in . “They made audio tapes of the torture, they would kick back, open a Guinness and play it over again,” Douglas said. “You could hear the screams. It was nauseating, I could only listen to a few seconds.” Douglas was the inspiration for FBI character Jack Crawford in the Hannibal Lecter movies, and worked with producers during the filming of Silence of the Lambs. To hammer home the true horror of his work, he played a segment of Bittaker and Norrisapos audio to Scott Glenn, who played Crawford, ahead of filming. “He was in tears, he was so emotional,” Douglas recalled. “Until then he said he was against the death penalty, but that changed it.” As a young agent he was determined to speak to serial killers to find outthere were any similarities that could help identy other murderers faster. From his work came the realisation that animal cruelty as a child could be a sign of evil deeds to come, and many experienced dficult childhoods. “They lack empathy, they see themselves as the victim,” said Douglas.   “They canapost identy with those they kill. If you do get them to cry, theyaposre putting on an act. “You have to show a feigned empathy with them to get what you want. Some agents would get angry and want to choke the guy, but you canapost do that. “I would find myself looking in the face of one of them and youaposd try to imagine what this face would look like when they were raping and murdering their victims, what the victim would see in the last moments of their le. “In most cases they donapost look like theyaposre capable of the crimes they committed, but you know theyaposre guilty.”  Kemper, who killed  including his grandparents and mother, was the first killer to be interviewed by Douglas and his small team. “He was talking about disposing of his motheraposs body, joking about it,” he said. “After we did that interview myself and the other agent got in the car and looked at each other, exhausted. We both needed a drink.”  Another breakthrough Douglas recalls was with Dennis Rader, who became known as the BTK killer – which stood for aposBind, Torture and Killapos. He was responsible for  deaths between  and . “I asked him what motivated him, and he said it was all about the rope,” Douglas revealed. “His thing was bondage, he sent sketches of his victims to the police.  “The main question I wanted to ask him was why he stopped for three years at a time. “In answer to that he told me heaposd got caught. One day he came home at lunchtime and put on a female victimaposs clothes and face mask, he was into autoeroticism. “His we walked in on him, but she never put two-and-two together and realised he was the BTK killer. “He said: aposJohn, I only stopped because I got caught.apos” At its height, Douglasapos department would be working on , cases a year. He believes there are between  and  serial killers carrying out murders each year in the United States - and poor communication between hundreds of law enforcement agencies means many are getting away with their crimes longer than they could be.  In Netflix show Mindhunters, which is due tofor a second series in the summer, Douglas is represented by idealistic young agent Holden Ford, played by Jonathan Groff. “The first series begins to show the toll that his work takes on him,” said Douglas. “I suffered anxiety attacks because of it. “In  I was teaching in New York City and I thought I was having a heart attack.” Days later, at the age of , he collapsed in a hotel room in Seattle. “I nearly died,” he said. “I laid on the floor for three days because I had a do not disturb sign on the door. “I was in a coma, and it needed months of rehabilitation. “I told the bureau that I couldnapostto active duty because I couldnapost lt a firearm, but they told me they just needed my brain. “At that time my brain was shot to pieces.” Nevertheless it would be more than a decade until Douglas retired from the FBI in . His first book, Mindhunter, was published the same year. Douglasapos second book, The Killer Across The Table, was released on May . On June  he will be the keynote speaker at the Eventim Apollo in Hammersmith, where members of the public can hear him speak at True Crime in Conversation.

story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: thought for the week march 22 2019
story: Hannah OHanlonUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAs a very enthusiastic, though amateur, photographer, I had treated myself to a new and rather expensive camera lens.Usually I purchase an inexpensive skylight filter to protect the lens from scratches or damage.The theory being that it is far easier and less expensive to replace an inexpensive filter than a very expensive lens.However I was intrigued when I began to research the best filter for my requirements.I was being offered a completely clear glass filter for way more than I would normally pay for a simple skylight filter.At first I thought: #Why on earth would I pay such a lot of money for something which is just a piece of clear glass #However when I read the reasons given to purchase this clear piece of glass, I was convinced.The logic was this – why pay a lot of money for a top-class lens, and then put a cheap filter on it Why not let the lens do the job you have paid it to do, and simply protect it with the finest clearest glass you can get.I thought of the words of St Paul who said: #For now we see through a glass, darkly but then face to face: now I know in part but then shall I know even as also I am known.#Somehow my clear glass filter gives me the best image reproduction I can have.In our earthly le, we see Jesus as best we can, perhaps through a skylight filter, but just think that in time there will be nothing to dull our vision and we will see him in all his glory # crystal clear and face to face.

title: letters week 12
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,This is a short note of thanks to all who made my th birthday party at Chalmers Court such a success.I did not help a great deal by having a bad fall near the bus stop on my way for the morning papers and am lucky not to have broken bones. A bruised and battered face caused alarm on first viewing which gave way to quite a lot of laughter and bold comment.But what a delightful party, laid on by our warden Sheena Stewart and ladies and saw we all had tea, coffee, and home baking, including shortbread and sconesand presents of wine and malt whiskey. What a lovely morning.To all who sent cards for my th, including the community council, the Wednesday Club, the Inveraray Highland Games , my warmest thanks. And many thanks to those who helped me up after my fall and in particular Stuart Campbell of Brambles who took me to the surgery, whose very kind people cleaned me up and sent me on my way to my party half an hour later.And a mention to Take the Floor too on Radio Scotland on Saturday night. Thank you Inveraray and District Accordion and Fiddle Club and Margaret Mather our secretary for this request.So I won#t forget my th in a hurry, but such kindness and friendliness cannot be forgotten ever.My thanks to you all,Niall Iain MacLean, InveraraySir,I read with great interest the letter in the March  edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser from C Rees, Lochgilphead.In addition to all that was mentioned I wonderyour readers are acquainted with the McCrone Report which was written in the s As I’m sure your readers are aware this was when oil had just started flowing from the North Sea. Mr Gavin McCrone was, at that time, a civil servant instructed to write a report on the possible effects of North Sea Oil on the argument for Scotland’s devolution.This quote comes from a letter written, by Mr McCrone, in April : #The Paper was written over a year ago in the weeks immediately before the February  election. This will be particularly apparent on page  where, of course, the ministerial pronouncements referred to relate to the Conservative Government.#So he was instructed to write this report by a Conservative Government but was reporting to a Labour Government.This quote comes from the end of the letter: #When my paper was written it was classied “secret” and given only a most restricted circulation in the Scottish Office because of the extreme sensitivity of the subject.#The report discussed the possibility of Scottish Independence and came to the conclusion: #What is quite clear is that the balance of payments gain from North Sea oil would easily swamp the existing deficit whatever its size and transform Scotland into a country with a substantial and chronic surplus.#Now, this is a very tiny segment from a document that could have changed our history but that’s in the past and we must now look to the future.What is upsetting is thatthis wealth had been invested in an oil fund or more fairly distributed by the  British Government # either Conservative or Labour # there might not, now, be an upsurge in support for separation from Westminster.Wilma Watts, TarbertSir,With Theresa May’s Brexit deal yet again failing to get through the House of Commons and a delay to the date the UK is due to leave the EU, it is clear that we are simply lurching from crisis to crisis.One wonders what good an extension will actually do given the negotiating position of both the EU and the UK. The UK is deadlocked, in terms of its people, Parliament and Cabinet and the likelihood of any semblance of a deal that command the majority of the House of Commons is unlikely. This is especially true given the deep isions within the Tories, both Remainers and Leavers, as well as opposition from the DUP.Given this situation those like myself have long argued that a UK-wide referendum on the deal, a so-called ‘People’s Vote’, with the option to remain in the EU, is the only credible way to break this deadlock. For those who argue that this would damage our democratic process, I am not sure we can slump any lower than the situation we are currently in.As David Davis, the former Brexit Secretary and an ardent Leaver, pointed out before the EU referendum: #If a democracy cannot change its mind, it ceases to be a democracy.#There are few I know who voted for Brexit in the belief it would make them poorer, and it is up to the public to give its view on whether the deal, and more importantly its implications, are what it wants.For once I agree with Jacob Rees-Mogg who previously supported a vote on the renegotiated settlement. A statement he now curiously seems to have forgotten.The Scottish Parliament has led the way in backing a People’s Vote and now that we know the precise nature of the deal, it is up to the public to have its say.Alex Orr, Edinburgh

title: letters to the editor week 18 2
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,I read with interest the article in the April  edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser about the council’s autism strategy.I find it strange Councillor Green said the #strategy has reached a draft stage# when an Autism Strategy for Argyll and Bute already exists.It was commissioned by the council, produced in May  and signed off by council members. An implementation plan was produced in December  to cover the years -. Who in Argyll and Bute is responsible for this plan  How many of the outcomes have been achieved As someone who has been involved with autism personally and professionally for many years, I find it extremely disappointing there seems to be an inability by those in authority to get organised enough to address the issues and provide services for autistic people and their families.There is no need for further drafts and consultations.Someone in the authority needs to take responsibility for the existing strategy and implementation plan and get on with it.Maureen Mackintosh, Ardrishaig.Sir,Scotland’s small building firms had a strong start to , in contrast to the UK construction small and medium sized enterprisesector, according to the Federation of Master BuildersScotland.The FMB State of Trade Survey for the first quarter of , the only quarterly assessment of the UK-wide SME construction sector, showed SME workloads declined for the first time in six years.In Scotland, however, there was a jump of  per cent compared with the previous quarter. Thirty per cent of weighted responses were positive, up from  per cent from the fourth quarter of .It is encouraging the Scottish construction industry is bucking the wider Brexit trend with workloads and enquires in rude health. The UK-wide picture is very dferent, with the construction SME sector overall contracting for the first time in six years.Scotland’s good fortune could be due to fewer EU workers being based north of the border compared with other parts of the country, like in London where one in three construction workers are from the EU.Relying less heavily on migrant workers has meant the Scottish construction industry hasn’t fallen foul of thousands of EU workers ing home during the long march to Brexit due to no longer feeling welcome in the UK or sure of their future here.Scotland’s builders, however, must not be complacent. Looking ahead, the First Minister has indicated thatthe UK does leave the EU later this year, she wants a second independence referendum before the next Scottish Parliament election in . This additional political uncertainty, on top of the continued uncertainty stemming from Brexit, could impact on the construction sector in Scotland.The fear is a looming second referendum could test consumer confidence this year and next. For construction SMEs, this is particularly concerning as their prospects are vulnerable to dips in consumer confidence as so much work comes from the private domestic sector.Gordon Nelson, Director of FMB Scotland.Sir,I was joined by my fellow Conservative councillors in Kilmory recently as we discussed atthe numerous challenges facing Argyll and Bute.Ferry sailings, roads, education and the SNP#s late single farm payments were all mentioned.With the SNP hammering local authority spending and cutting our budgets, challenges in delivering services will become more prevalent.Despite this climate of cuts from the separatists, Conservative councillors are delivering for Argyll. This includes extra funding for the Tarbert and Lochgilphead Regeneration Fund, more funding for infrastructure and an increase in roads winter maintenance resources across Argyll.As ever, my fellow Conservatives and I will continue to fight non stop to make sure our rural constituency is not sidelined by this unceasingly urban and separatism-obsessed over centralising Scottish Government.Councillor Alastair Redman, Kintyre and Islands ward.Sir,I photographed this unusual visitor to Kilduskland Road, Ardrishaig, on April . Magpies are not a regular feature in Mid Argyll. We have not seen one in more than  years here.I think I saw a second one, either in pursuit or being pursued.Ron MacInnes, Ardrishaig.PIC:The Ardrishaig magpie, spotted in April. no_aMagpie

Plans are now afoot for a further event in May to create an installation that looks at the impact of plastic on the countryside.Most recently three of the leaders, David Smart, Anne Smart and John McCartan took the chance to abseil  feet off the Falkirk Wheel. The Beavers will be attending a district fun day in May and the Cubs will be participating in a district trophy event in June.The Scouts are heading to a national Scout adventure camp in May and the Explorers are organising an adventurous activities camp in June.Scout leader David Smart said: #In late June th Argyll Scout Group is expecting to host two Norwegian Scout visitors and in July,  members of the group will be heading off for international adventures. Six young people and two leaders are travelling to Malaysia to undertake community projects in a remote northern village and two Explorers will participate in the th World Scout Jamboree in the USA.He continued: #We are sad that our Beaver leader Eli is leaving us for pastures new. We would like to thank her for all her help and wish her well in her new job.#There are lots of opportunities for young people both boys and girls aged  to  and adults to join th Argyll Scouts and develop skills for le.Please contact David Smart for more information by email at thargyllscouts@gmail or call  .PICS:Anya Gritten, Logan Allan, Toby MacDonald, Bea Catterwell, Polly Payne and Anna Turner receive their Gold Chief Scout Awards at Lochgoilhead National Scout Centre. no_aScouts Beavers, Cubs, Scouts, Explorers and Leaders at Lochgoilhead. no_aScoutsEarth Hour Camp at Heart of Argyll Wildle Organisation. no_aScoutsAnne Smart abseiling off the Falkirk Wheel. no_aScouts

title: hope springs eternal just off the argyll coast
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowArgyll marine conservation groups have joined forces to have a chunk of our coastal waters declared a #Hope Spot# # in a first for the British Isles.The breathtaking iety of le and stunning scenery on land which we are familiar with in Argyll is,anything, surpassed under our coastal waters.It is one of the most biologically erse marine regions in Scotland and the UK so a number of conservation groups # CAOLAS, covering the area around Loch Sunart CROMACH, interested in the Loch Craignish area Friends of the Sound of Jura and Save Seil Sound # decided to pursue a Hope Spot for the region.Under the auspices of international marine conservation organisation Mission Blue, Hope Spots are areas of sea around the globe where hope remains. Places where le is still winning.And so the Argyll and the Islands Hope Spot was born # or soon will be, since the formal launch will not happen until June .Speaking at a celebration and unofficial unveiling at Craignish Village Hall on May  was renowned wildle photographer and film-maker John Aitchison, from north Knapdale.He joined a call to action, echoed by other speakers during the evening, to work to create a sustainable future for all species, humans included.#The situation is very stark very clear,# he said. #We cannot delay in improving bioersity in the seas and on land.#He cited the example of the flapper skate, a species found in the Sound of Jura but internationally in such a precarious state that it is now more endangered than the giant panda.Another speaker, tour guide and photographer Philip Price, continued the theme, saying: #Hope Spots represent international recognition of what we have # and what could be here.#But this cannot be a flash in the pan, so the more people who are involved the better.#The upbeat mood in the packed hall was capped with a congratulatory message from Mission Blue founder and president Sylvia Earle.In a special video, she said: #Thank you for being the first # but hopefully not the last # Hope Spot in Scotland and the UK.#There is a chance, thanks to people like you who care.#

title: rusty padlocks no more new owner talks about plans to re open inveraray pier
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsThe new owner of Inveraray#s iconic but neglected pier has plans to re-open it to the public # but only after refurbishment work is complete.The pier has been purchased by the Colonsay-based Byrne family, owners of the nearby Inveraray Inn.Earlier this week company director Geaspar Byrne spoke exclusively to the Argyllshire Advertiser about the reasons for buying the pier and what lies ahead.Mr Byrne said: #I have an interest in Inveraray and want to see it doing well. It is obvious to everyone that the pier not being open is a resource wasted.#Inveraray Pier has been in existence since . Comprising an older stone-built section and later timber structure, it was once a thriving hub for Inveraray#s herring fleet and a popular destination for passenger steamers. It was used by everything from pleasure craft to puffers, with the military also making good use of it over the years.In more recent times it has fallen into disrepair and was closed off to public access in the last decade.#When we heard it was for sale we decided to make a bid,# continued Mr Byrne.#It would have been a shame to see it fall into the hands of someone who would want to use it just as a private pier. It#s about securing its future.#The Byrne family intends to re-open the pier for public use # but Mr Byrne is keen to dampen speculation about the potential future uses for the structure.Before anything  happens, the condition of the stone and wooden sections must be assessed, and reports have been commissioned from engineers and conservation architects.#I don#t want to raise expectation unnecessarily, but the most likely scenario is that we look to re-open the stone pier first of all,# explained Mr Byrne.Repairs would be needed to the stone structure and ironwork. New handrails and safety equipment would be needed along with lighting and basic security measures such as CCTV.Beyond that, the future of the wooden pier looks less certain.refurbishment is not an option, alternatives might include floating pontoons, while the potential for dredging around the pier and harbour might be considered.Through an agent, The Argyll Partnership, the Byrne family has contacted the Clyde Marine Planning Partnership with a view to having Inveraray included in the fledgling Clyde Regional Marine Plan, stressing that the pier #represents a great opportunity to contribute to the economic, social and environmental needs of the Clyde Marine Region#.And the new owners have said that the community council, Inspire Inveraray and others from the area will be fully involved as the redevelopment takes shape. The plans are also said to have the backing of the Duke of Argyll.Mr Byrne concluded: #Hopefully local people will want to help and come forward with ideas.#I don#t want to raise hopes at this early stage, but I hope that buying the pier is a good thing to do.#

title: jake gets his message across to jura
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +viaYOURTWITTERNAMEHERE" title"Tweet this"TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowStrolling along the beach while on an Easter break to her native Isle of Jura, Patsy Boyle noticed a plastic water bottle lying above the high water mark.At first dismissing it as just another piece of marine litter, she noticed something inside the bottle # a piece of paper.The romance of sending or finding a message in a bottle may be fading a little as marine pollution becomes an ever more prominent issue # but for the seven-year-old lad who sent the message, it was a real thrill to discover that it had been found.Jake Curtis was inspired to send his note after reading a story in the Argyllshire Advertiser about a message in a bottle turning up on the shores of Loch Fyne at Furnace.So, on February  this year he set off on his dad#s fishing boat into the Sound of Jura from Carsaig, near Tayvallich.On a piece of paper, carefully sealed in a plastic pouch and with a mobile phone number included, he wrote: #To whoever finds this, my name is Jake. My favourite things to do are playing my X-Box and Nintendo Switch and snuggling with my mum.#I have a sister called Holly and she is six. I have been fishing with my dad and threw this into the sea.#Please let me knowyou find this. Thank you, from Jake.#The bottle floated on the Sound of Jura before Patsy spotted it almost three months later on Knockrome shore, near Craighouse, blown well above the high tide mark by easterly winds.In sharp contrast to the leisurely progress of the original note, Patsy replied to Jake by st century methods using text messaging, telling him she#d found the bottle.Patsy, from London, told the Advertiser: #He was so excited to hear it had been found.
